title: Netflix’s When They See Us hit with lawsuit over interrogation technique
text:
When They See Us is facing a defamation lawsuit (Picture: Netflix)

Netflix’s When They See Us has been hit with a defamation lawsuit over the show’s representation of an interrogation technique.

Ava DuVernay’s critically praised miniseries charts the true story of the 1989 Central Park jogger case, where five African-American men were wrongfully incarcerated for sexual assault.

In a strange turn of events, the show has been sued by a company who are barely mentioned in the series, who claim an interrogation technique they pioneered was wrongfully represented.

John E. Reid is a former police officer turned consultant who spearheaded the ‘Reid Technique’ interrogation method, and has been teaching it since 1974 to clients (according to his lawsuit) including the FBI, US military and police departments.

The show follows the case of the Central Park Five (Picture: Netflix)

His company, John E. Reid and Associates, Inc, have took particular umbrage with a scene in the final episode, where a discussion takes place between Manhattan assistant D.A. Nancy Ryan (Famke Janssen) and a New York City detective involved in abstracting confessions from the accused.

In this scene, Ryan’s partner says: ‘You squeezed statements out of them after 42 hours of questioning and coercing, without food, bathroom breaks, withholding parental supervision. The Reid Technique has been universally rejected. That’s truth to you.’

The lawsuit (available here) is strongly against the idea the Reid Technique has been ‘universally rejected’ – and claims it has been falsely represented by being associated with these attributes.

‘The program falsely represents that squeezing and coercing statements from juvenile subjects after long hours of questioning without food, bathroom breaks or parental supervision is synonymous with the Reid Technique,’ the lawsuit states.

Metro.co.uk reached out to Netflix who had no comment.

Considering the show doesn’t explicitly mention John Reid’s company, it’s questionable how far the lawsuit will go – although it does state the Reid Technique is a trademark which could give it more legitimacy.

When They See Us earned 16 nominations at this year’s Emmys, with actor Jharell Jerome picking up the award for Outstanding Lead Actor in a Limited Series.

You can catch When They See Us streaming on Netflix.
